**Red Hot Chilli Pipers** are an ensemble consisting of
[pipers](/wiki/Bagpipes "Bagpipes"), guitarists, keyboards and drummers formed
in [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") in 2002. They entered and won the
[BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") talent show [_When Will I Be
Famous?_](/wiki/When_Will_I_Be_Famous%3F_\(TV_series\) "When Will I Be Famous?
\(TV series\)")[1] in 2007. Their name is a play on the American band the [Red
Hot Chili Peppers](/wiki/Red_Hot_Chili_Peppers "Red Hot Chili Peppers").

In 2004, the group appeared on the main stage at [T in the
Park](/wiki/T_in_the_Park "T in the Park") with the headline band, the rock
group [The Darkness](/wiki/The_Darkness_\(band\) "The Darkness \(band\)").
They appeared on [BBC Radio 1](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1 "BBC Radio 1") on the [Greg
James](/wiki/Greg_James "Greg James") show in July 2013[2] and [The Radio 1
Breakfast Show](/wiki/The_Radio_1_Breakfast_Show "The Radio 1 Breakfast Show")
with [Nick Grimshaw](/wiki/Nick_Grimshaw "Nick Grimshaw") in 2014.[3]

The band
currently[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] has Grant Cassidy – an 8 time
world champion [snare](/wiki/Snare_drum "Snare drum") drummer.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Hot_Chilli_Pipers&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Since their formation the Red Hot Chilli Pipers have combined guitars,
keyboards, drums and their bagpipes to create 'bagrock' sound. The Red Hot
Chilli Pipers perform a fusion of traditional pipe tunes and contemporary
pieces. Notable covers performed have included "[We Will Rock
You](/wiki/We_Will_Rock_You "We Will Rock You")" by
[Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(band\) "Queen \(band\)"),
"[Clocks](/wiki/Clocks_\(song\) "Clocks \(song\)")" by
[Coldplay](/wiki/Coldplay "Coldplay") and "[Smoke on the
Water](/wiki/Smoke_on_the_Water "Smoke on the Water")" by [Deep
Purple](/wiki/Deep_Purple "Deep Purple") as well as "[Chasing
Cars](/wiki/Chasing_Cars "Chasing Cars")" by [Snow Patrol](/wiki/Snow_Patrol
"Snow Patrol"), "[Don't Stop Believing](/wiki/Don%27t_Stop_Believing "Don't
Stop Believing")" by [Journey](/wiki/Journey_\(band\) "Journey \(band\)").
Their biggest hit to date is of course the platinum selling and award winning
Jazz Badger.

The band has released 6 studio albums as of 2016, of which their first, their
2005 release _The Red Hot Chilli Pipers_ , was the least successful. Their
2007 album _Bagrock to the Masses_ went platinum in Scotland and silver in
Great Britain. Their third album and first live album, _Blast Live_ (2008),
went triple platinum in Scotland. Their fourth release _Music for the Kilted
Generation_ , however, is The Red Hot Chilli Pipers' best International
record, reaching Number 2 on the US Amazon Chart.[4] and was only held off of
the top spot due to [Adele](/wiki/Adele "Adele")'s record-breaking album,
_[21](/wiki/21_\(Adele_album\) "21 \(Adele album\)")_.

Their album titled _Music for the Kilted Generation_ , is a parody of _[Music
for the Jilted Generation](/wiki/Music_for_the_Jilted_Generation "Music for
the Jilted Generation")_ by [The Prodigy](/wiki/The_Prodigy "The Prodigy").

The band signed a contract in December 2012 for a new album to be released in
2013, including tracks from bands like Coldplay and
[Journey](/wiki/Journey_\(band\) "Journey \(band\)"). _Breathe_ was released
in July 2013 on CD and [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes").

The group appears on the soundtrack of _[How to Train Your Dragon
2](/wiki/How_to_Train_Your_Dragon_2 "How to Train Your Dragon 2")._[5]

The group's highest profile performance's have been on the Main Stage at [T in
the Park](/wiki/T_in_the_Park "T in the Park") in 2004 where they performed
alongside The Darkness, and in 2014 when they performed on the Main Stage
again in their own right.

### When Will I Be
Famous[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Hot_Chilli_Pipers&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: When Will I Be Famous")]

In 2007, the Red Hot Chilli Pipers appeared on the BBC show _When Will I be
Famous?_[7] hosted by [Graham Norton](/wiki/Graham_Norton "Graham Norton").
The band were in the episode and competed against seven others. The eight
contestants were paired into a head-to-head showdown in which the winner would
be decided by 101 preregistered viewers who were dubbed the "Armchair Judges".
The four winners of these head-to-heads would then compete against each other
in the second show with the winner being decided by an open public phone vote.
In their first head-to-head showdown, The Red Hot Chilli Pipers were pitted
against the "Stringfever", a four-member string quartet. The Red Hot Chilli
Pipers won the head-to-head 51-50 and went on to win the weekly prize of ten
thousand pounds.

### After TV
appearance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Hot_Chilli_Pipers&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: After TV appearance")]

In 2010, The Red Hot Chilli Pipers completed an 11-date sold-out tour of
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), as well as an 11-week tour of Germany
and a 7-week tour of [America](/wiki/United_States "United States"). They also
toured [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia"),
[Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia"), [India](/wiki/India "India") and most
of Europe. They performed concerts in New York and Beijing as well as at the
[Hebridean Celtic Festival](/wiki/Hebridean_Celtic_Festival "Hebridean Celtic
Festival") in [Stornoway](/wiki/Stornoway "Stornoway").

##
Musicianship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Hot_Chilli_Pipers&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Musicianship")]

With a total of 4 degrees from the [Royal Conservatoire of
Scotland](/wiki/Royal_Conservatoire_of_Scotland "Royal Conservatoire of
Scotland"), many of the band members past & present have competed at the
highest level of bagpiping and drumming for many years. Founder and Former
Musical Director Cassells received 'BBC Radio Scotland Young Traditional
Musician of the Year' in 2005 and became the first person ever to attain a
degree in bagpipes[8] from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland (Formerly the
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama). The snare drummer and
percussionist, Grant Cassidy is an 8 time Juvenile Solo World Drumming
Champion and in 2016 placed 7th in the adult section of the World Solo
Drumming Championships held in Glasgow, Scotland.

## Former
members[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Hot_Chilli_Pipers&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Former members")]

On 23 September 2011, founder and [frontman](/wiki/Frontman "Frontman") Stuart
Cassells, left the band. Stuart decided that, after almost ten years, it was
time to pursue new goals and opportunities. Cassells said, "I have had some
absolutely amazing times in the band and I would never have imagined the
success we’ve had. I want to thank all the great musicians I’ve had the
pleasure of performing with and I’m excited about the new chapter in my life".
Prior to leaving, Stuart had been struggling with '[focal hand
dystonia'](/wiki/Cognitive_neuroscience_of_music#Focal_hand_dystonia
"Cognitive neuroscience of music"), more commonly known as [writer's
cramp](/wiki/Writer%27s_cramp "Writer's cramp") since 2008. Speaking to _[The
Daily Record](/wiki/Daily_Record_\(Scotland\) "Daily Record \(Scotland\)")_ on
the subject, Cassells said, "My left hand refused to stay on the chanter. It
was like my left hand wasn't my own, it wouldn't stay still, like someone else
was controlling it. I knew in my head how I wanted to play but I couldn't
because my hands would curl right up and tense up and move involuntarily. They
weren't doing what they were supposed to do. The brain was sending far too
many signals to my hands." Stuart tried various treatments throughout this
period, including surgery to release a trapped nerve,
[physiotherapy](/wiki/Physiotherapy "Physiotherapy") and [botox](/wiki/Botox
"Botox") injections into his arm to relax the muscles. In efforts to help him
play the bagpipes, he had [McCallum Bagpipes](/wiki/McCallum_Bagpipes
"McCallum Bagpipes") manufacture him a custom chanter that uses flute keys to
cover the holes instead of requiring the player to cover them. However, he was
still unable to play them and left the band. It is hoped that he will recover
and rejoin the band. A recent World Pipe Band Championship winner with the
Field Marshal Montgomery Pipe Band, Kyle Warren, replaced him.[9][10]

nq_3054_1.Query Analysis: The query asks for the formation year of the band 'Red Hot Chilli Pipers'.
nq_3054_1.Query Keywords Extraction: Red Hot Chilli Pipers, form, when
nq_3054_1.Answer Analysis: The answer is 2002, indicating the year the band was formed.
nq_3054_1.Document Content Analysis: The document provides information about the Red Hot Chilli Pipers, including their formation year, members, and some of their achievements and appearances.
